nodes.text: Agents maximize the time-average growth rate of wealth and expected-utility theory can be given a dynamical interpretation by identifying the utility function with the ergodicity transformation of underlying wealth dynamics
Ergodicity economics models wealth as a stochastic process (wealth dynamics) and posits the relevant maximand for individuals is the time-average growth rate of wealth along a single trajectory
Expected utility theory (EUT) ranks actions by the expectation of changes in a nonlinear transform of wealth, the utility function, traditionally interpreted as psychological preference

For the time-average growth-rate criterion to be well defined it is sufficient to transform wealth by a monotonic function u(x) whose additive increments are stationary and independent, i.e. u(t) follows a Brownian motion with drift du = a_u dt + b_u dW
When u(t) is a Brownian motion with drift the long-time limit of the rate r = Delta u / Delta t exists and equals the drift a_u, making r an ergodic observable (time average equals ensemble average)
Consequently, expected-utility maximization using u(x) is equivalent to maximizing the time-average growth rate under the corresponding wealth dynamics

Given an invertible utility function u(x) with sufficient smoothness, Ito's lemma applied to du = a_u dt + b_u dW yields an explicit stochastic differential equation dx = a_x(x) dt + b_x(x) dW for wealth, so each invertible u corresponds to a unique wealth dynamic

Conversely, for an Ito wealth process dx = a_x(x) dt + b_x(x) dW a necessary and sufficient consistency condition for a mapping to a Brownian utility process is bu = b_x(x) u'(x) with constant bu and resulting constraint a_x(x) = (a_u/b_u) b_x(x) + (1/2) b_x(x) b_x'(x)

Under this correspondence, the utility function acquires a physical interpretation as the ergodicity transformation determined by exogenous wealth dynamics, so apparent risk preferences are predicted from dynamics rather than assumed fixed

The paper provides illustrative examples: linear u(x)=x yields additive (Brownian) wealth dynamics; logarithmic u(x)=ln x yields geometric Brownian motion; square-root u(x)=sqrt(x) yields mixed additive-multiplicative dynamics
Knowing u(x) lets one derive the full time-dependent wealth distribution Px(x,t) by transforming the normal distribution of u(t): Pu(u,t)=Normal(a_u t, b_u^2 t) and Px(x,t)=Pu(u(x),t) du/dx

The correspondence explains why different observed utility functions arise from different wealth dynamics, predicts that changing dynamics will change apparent preferences, and provides a theoretical basis for choosing utility functions in EUT
Empirical work with controllable wealth dynamics supports the prediction that dynamics are strong determinants of preferences
The framework requires invertible utility functions, continuous-path processes (so u is Brownian with drift), and the assumption that time between decision and outcome is independent of action

Limitations and formal choices include excluding pathological processes that do not admit an ergodicity transformation, and the formalism favors unbounded utility functions because bounded u(x) are noninvertible or create finite-time singularities
